docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Robin Cook (''Decoding Health Insurance,'' Op-Ed, May 22) says that as a doctor, he has found that ''the doctor-patient relationship is the most personal and rewarding for both the patient and the doctor when a clear, direct fiduciary relationship exists.'' For 20 years I have been a salaried staff doctor in a hospital whose mission is to serve all regardless of ability to pay, and I have always felt a special privilege in being able to care for patients without having a commercial aspect to the relationship.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a short strike, workers at a Coca-Cola Enterprises bottling plant in East Hartford approved a new contract on Saturday and were to return to work early today, said Chris Roos, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 1035. About 350 plant workers walked out on May 23 over the company's demand that they make a direct contribution to their health insurance. The two sides agreed to terms on Thursday after the company dropped that condition, and on Saturday, the employees voted 258 to 23 to approve the new contract. The six-year pact increases wages an average of 3.2 percent per year, Mr. Roos says, and significantly raises the company's contribution to health care and other benefits.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: East Hartford: Bottling Workers To Return

docs.lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old girl got into in a fight with an 11-year-old girl in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday -- family members said it was over a ball -- and killed her by plunging a steak knife into her chest, the police said. The stabbing in the apartment building at 185 Wortman Avenue in East New York left the police scrambling to determine the appropriate charges for the youngest suspect in a killing that anyone in the department could recall. And it left the family of the slain girl, Queen Washington, not only grappling with the horror of her death, but also trying to grasp just how someone so young could possibly be responsible.

headline.main: Police Hold 9-Year-Old Girl In Killing Of Friend, 11

byline.original: By JENNIFER 8. LEE and COLIN MOYNIHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: At 71, after nearly half a century in the union movement and after a decade leading the nation's main labor federation, John J. Sweeney is facing his toughest time ever. The percentage of American workers belonging to unions continues to fall, President Bush is seeking to weaken collective bargaining rights for 700,000 federal workers, and many unionized companies are cutting back once-unassailable benefits, like health insurance and pensions.

headline.main: A Summer of Discontent for Labor Focuses on Its Leader's Fitness for His Job

docs.snippet: After a decade leading the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney is facing his toughest time ever, and the biggest battle may be a nasty internal struggle.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF LABOR-CONGRESS OF INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATIONS

docs.lead_paragraph: GOOD times seem like they should bring good health. More people have jobs and health insurance when an economy is growing. Fewer people skip visits to the doctor to save money or suffer the severe stress that comes with a layoff. So with job growth now stronger than it has been since 2000, the country can look forward to some vigorous years, it might seem. But that is not quite how the world works, some new research has found. In fact, a strong economy should probably come with a warning label. A one-percentage-point fall in the unemployment rate -- which is what has happened since the summer of 2003 -- leads to 12,000 deaths a year in the United States that might not otherwise have happened, according to Christopher J. Ruhm, an economist at the University of North Carolina, Greensboro.

headline.main: Warning: If Signs of an Economic Recovery Persist, See Your Doctor Immediately

docs.snippet: A study by an economist at the University of North Carolina, Greensboro, has found that good economic times can increase risks to health.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when Congress has been torn by partisan battles, 24 ideologically disparate leaders representing the health care industry, corporations and unions, and conservative and liberal groups have been meeting secretly for months to seek a consensus on proposals to provide coverage for the growing number of people with no health insurance. The participants, ranging from the liberal Families USA to the conservative Heritage Foundation and the United States Chamber of Commerce, said they had made progress in trying to overcome the ideological impasse that has stymied action on the problem for eight years.

headline.main: HEALTH LEADERS SEEK CONSENSUS OVER UNINSURED

docs.snippet: Ideologically disparate leaders have been meeting to seek a consensus on coverage for people with no health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The United States could create a more efficient and fairer health system by modernizing today's burdensome legislative, regulatory and tax policies that artificially segment the insurance marketplace. Risks could be shared among millions of people with private health insurance, and insurers and health plans could buy private reinsurance against the costs of very large medical expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-15 Nuclear Pride in Iran A widespread sense of pride in Iran over its nuclear development effort complicates any attempt to persuade the country's leaders to give up parts of that program, as European negotiators have been trying to do in talks over the past few months. 1 The Bush administration is expanding efforts to influence Iran's internal politics, with aid for opposition and pro-democracy groups and lengthened broadcasts criticizing the Iranian government, administration officials say. 8 A Tug of War in France The debate leading up to the referendum in France on the European constitution has changed France's political landscape, and it faces a long political season of account-settling at home -- in addition to the reckoning it faces with its European partners if voters reject the treaty. 4 Brazil's Hunger Plan Lags Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's ''Zero Hunger'' program was supposed to be the centerpiece of his ambitious social transformation. But more than two years after the start of a pilot program, it has fallen far short of expectations. 6 Death Toll Rises in Iraq The surge of violence that has swept Iraq in May continued unabated, with at least 30 new deaths across the country, some of them in what appeared to be sectarian killings. 14 Lebanon Holds Elections As the city of Beirut prepared for the first round of Lebanon's parliamentary elections with a few campaign events, there is little evidence of actual campaigning. Little outreach has been made to the average voter. Instead, most crucial decisions have been made in backroom deals. 10 NATIONAL 16-26 Missile Defense for Airliners Congress has directed the Department of Homeland Security to move rapidly to take a high-tech missile defense system designed for military aircraft and adapt it to protect the nation's 6,800 commercial jets. 1 Spotting Class Differences Rising incomes, flattening prices and easily available credit have given so many Americans access to such a wide array of high-end goods that traditional markers of social status have lost much of their meaning. But status symbols have not disappeared. 1 Pondering Insurance Issues Leaders of the nation's health care system have been meeting secretly for seven months to seek a consensus on proposals to provide coverage for the growing number of people with no health insurance. 1 Landslide Haunts Residents In La Conchita, Calif., where 10 people were crushed to death in January by a massive landslide, the survivors continue to relive the disaster. 18 Reviving Judicial Fight The delicate compromise reached in the Senate to defuse a standoff over judicial confirmations is under mounting pressure from Republican leaders and conservative groups who are pressing Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, to revive the fight. 22 OBITUARIES 31 NEW YORK/REGION 33-38 Riding Waves in New York New York is not yet Surf Town USA, but it is experiencing a boom in surfing. The city's formal arrival as a recognized surfing destination came when the Parks Department designated a four-block stretch of Rockaway Beach in Queens for surfing only. 1 Fight Over Online Cigarettes As state officials fight illegal online cigarette sales, the United States Postal Service, citing concerns about the privacy of the mail and what it says would be the difficulty of putting postal clerks in the position of deciding which packages to accept and which to reject, is resisting the growing calls that it stop shipping cigarettes. 33 Chess 39 Weather 28

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Decoding Health Insurance'' (Op-Ed, May 22), Robin Cook says that the increasing ability of genetics to determine individuals' health risks will make our system of private insurance unworkable, and that we will therefore have to move to a system of universal health care. While I support that outcome, it is far from inevitable given the current political climate. Instead, we might experience a degradation of our current system, with those who are ''good risks'' obtaining private coverage and preference for employment, while ''bad risks'' go uncovered.

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER all the news media attention, finger-pointing and public displays of indignation about the closing of Southampton College, its 39th graduating class ended up with a pleasant enough commencement ceremony last Sunday. The speeches were congratulatory, the farewells appropriately bittersweet. Even the weather cooperated, the sun cutting through a cold, misty rain in time for the 457 degree recipients to line up for the ceremonial march across the sloping lawn. Except for the proverbial elephant in the room, this could have been any college's commencement.
